src: Les Babyloniens construisirent pour chacun de leurs dieux un temple principal qui était considéré comme la demeure du dieu. Les gens apportaient des sacrifices aux dieux et les prêtres essayaient de répondre aux besoins des dieux par le biais de cérémonies et de festivités. Chaque temple avait une cour ouverte, puis un sanctuaire intérieur auquel seuls les prêtres pouvaient accéder. Certaines tours pyramidales, les ziggourats, étaient parfois construites en tant qu’éléments d’un temple. Le sommet de la tour était un sanctuaire spécial pour le dieu.
mt: The Babylonians built a main temple for each of their gods, which was considered the god's dwelling place. People brought sacrifices to the gods and the priests tried to meet the needs of the gods through ceremonies and festivities. Each temple had an open courtyard, then an inner sanctuary to which only the priests could gain access. Sometimes pyramidal towers, ziggurats, were built as part of a temple. The top of the tower was a special sanctuary for the god.
ref: The Babylonians built each of their gods a primary temple that was considered the home of the god. People would bring sacrifices to the gods and the priests would try to attend to the needs of the gods through ceremonies and festivals. Each temple had an open temple courtyard and then an inner sanctuary that only the priests could enter. Sometimes special pyramid shaped towers, called ziggurats, were built to be a part of the temples. The top of the tower was special sanctuary for the god.

src: Oui ! Le roi Toutankhamon, parfois appelé « Roi Tout » ou « L’Enfant roi », est l’un des anciens monarques égyptiens les plus connus des temps modernes. Il est intéressant de noter qu’il n’était pas considéré comme très important dans l’Antiquité et n’était pas inscrit sur la plupart des anciennes listes de rois. Cependant, la découverte de sa tombe en 1922 a fait de lui une célébrité. Alors que de nombreuses tombes du passé ont été pillées, cette tombe est restée pratiquement intacte. La plupart des objets enterrés avec Toutankhamon ont été bien conservés, y compris des milliers d'artefacts faits de métaux précieux et de pierres rares.
mt: Yes! King Tutankhamun, sometimes called "King Tut" or "The Boy King", is one of the most famous ancient Egyptian monarchs of modern times. It is interesting to note that he was not considered very important in antiquity and was not listed on most ancient lists of kings. However, the discovery of his tomb in 1922 made him a celebrity. While many tombs of the past have been plundered, this tomb remained virtually intact. Most of the objects buried with Tutankhamun have been well preserved, including thousands of artifacts made of precious metals and rare stones.
ref: "Yes! King Tutankhamun, sometimes referred to as ""King Tut"" or ""The Boy King"", is one of the most well known ancient Egyptian kings in modern times. Interestingly, he was not considered to be very important in ancient times and was not recorded on most ancient king lists. However, the discovery of his tomb in 1922 made him a celebrity. While many tombs of the past were robbed, this tomb was left virtually undisturbed. Most of the items buried with Tutankhamun have been well preserved, including thousands of artefacts made from precious metals and rare stones."

src: Nous connaissons de nombreux hommes politiques, scientifiques et artistes grecs. Mais le plus célèbre de toute cette civilisation est probablement Homère, le poète aveugle auteur des deux plus grands chefs-d'œuvre de la littérature grecque : les poèmes de l'Iliade et l'Odyssée. Sophocle et Aristophane sont toujours des dramaturges populaires, et leurs pièces sont considérées comme faisant partie des plus grandes œuvres de la littérature mondiale. Un autre grec célèbre est le mathématicien Pythagore, surtout connu pour son célèbre théorème sur les relations des côtés des triangles rectangles.
mt: We know many Greek politicians, scientists and artists. But the most famous of all this civilization is probably Homer, the blind poet author of the two greatest masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems of the Iliad and the Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights, and their plays are considered part of the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is the mathematician Pythagoras, best known for his famous theorem on the relationships of the sides of right triangles.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: Dans le climat chaud du Moyen-Orient, la maison n'était pas si importante. La majeure partie de la vie de la famille hébraïque se déroulait en plein air. Les femmes cuisinaient dans la cour ; les magasins n'étaient que des comptoirs ouverts donnant sur la rue. Les maisons étaient bâties en pierres. Comme il n'y avait pas de grandes forêts en terre de Canaan, le bois était extrêmement cher.
mt: In the hot climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family took place outdoors. Women cooked in the courtyard; shops were just open counters facing the street. Houses were built of stone. As there were no large forests in the land of Canaan, wood was very expensive.
ref: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family happened in the open air. Women did the cooking in the yard; stores were just open counters looking into the street. Stone was used for building houses. There were no large forests in the land of Canaan, so wood was extremely expensive.

src: Le Groenland a été peu peuplé. Dans les sagas scandinaves, on raconte qu’Erik le Rouge a été exilé d’Islande pour meurtre qu’il a trouvé le Groenland — et l’a nommé ainsi — en voyageant plus à l’ouest. Mais indépendamment de sa découverte, des tribus esquimaudes y vivaient déjà à l’époque. Bien que chaque pays soit « scandinave », il existe de nombreuses différences entre les peuples, les rois, les coutumes et l'histoire du Danemark, de la Suède, de la Norvège, et de l'Islande.
mt: Greenland was sparsely populated. In the Scandinavian sagas, it is told that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder and found Greenland — and named it thus — by traveling further west. But regardless of its discovery, Inuit tribes already lived there at the time. Although each country is "Scandinavian", there are many differences between the peoples, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway, and Iceland.
ref: Greenland was settled sparsely. In the Norse sagas they say that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when travelling further west, found Greenland and named it Greenland. But regardless of his discovery, Eskimo tribes were already living there at the time. Though each country was 'Scandinavian', there were many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.

src: Bien que les Romains consommaient de la nourriture que nous connaissons, ils mangeaient certains plats de fête étranges ou inhabituels, notamment des sangliers, des paons, des escargots ainsi que le loir, une sorte de rongeur. Autre différence : alors que les pauvres et la femme mangeaient leur nourriture en étant assis sur des chaises, les hommes riches aimaient organiser des banquets ensemble où ils se reposaient sur le côté pendant qu’ils prenaient leur repas. Les repas romains de l'Antiquité ne pouvaient pas inclure ces aliments d'origine américaine ou asiatique qui ont été introduits en Europe des siècles plus tard. Par exemple, ils n'avaient pas de maïs, ni de tomates, ni de pommes de terre, ni de cacao, et aucun ancien Romain n'a jamais goûté de dinde.
mt: Although the Romans ate food we know, they ate some strange or unusual festival foods, including wild boars, peacocks, snails and the muskrat, a kind of rodent. Other differences: while the poor and women ate their food sitting on chairs, rich men liked to organize banquets together where they rested on the side while they took their meal. Roman meals of antiquity could not include these foods of American or Asian origin that were introduced to Europe centuries later. For example, they did not have corn, tomatoes, potatoes, or cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted turkey.
ref: While most of their food would be familiar to us, Romans did have their share of strange or unusual feast items, including wild boar, peacock, snails, and a type of rodent called a dormouse Another difference was that while the poor people and the woman ate their food while sitting in chairs, the rich men liked to have banquets together where they would lounge on their sides while they ate their meals. Ancient Roman meals couldn't have included foods that came to Europe from America or from Asia in later centuries. For instance, they didn't have corn, nor tomatoes, nor potatoes, nor cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted a turkey.

src: Une civilisation est une culture singulière partagée par un groupe important de personnes qui vivent et travaillent en coopération, une société. Le terme « civilisation » est dérivé du mot latin « civilis », qui signifie civil et qui est apparenté aux mots latins « civis », qui signifie citoyen, et « civitas », qui veut dire grande ville ou ville-État et qui indique aussi, en quelque sorte, la taille de la société à laquelle il se rapporte. Les villes-États sont les précurseurs des nations. Une culture civilisationnelle implique la transmission des connaissances sur plusieurs générations, une empreinte culturelle durable et une diffusion équitable. Les cultures minoritaires disparaissent souvent sans laisser de traces historiques pertinentes et ne sont pas reconnues comme de véritables civilisations.
mt: A civilization is a unique culture shared by a large group of people who live and work together in cooperation, a society. The term "civilization" is derived from the Latin word "civilis", which means civil and is related to the Latin words "civis", which means citizen, and "civitas", which means large city or city-state and which also indicates, in some way, the size of the society to which it refers. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the transmission of knowledge over several generations, a lasting cultural imprint and an equitable distribution. Minor cultures often disappear without leaving relevant historical traces and are not recognized as true civilizations.
ref: A civilization is a singular culture shared by a significant large group of people who live and work co-operatively, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin civilis, meaning civil, related to the Latin civis, meaning citizen, and civitas, meaning city or city-state, and that also somehow defines the size of the society. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

src: Le Drukgyal Dzong est une forteresse et un monastère bouddhiste en ruine dans la partie supérieure du district de Paro (dans le village de Phondey). On dit qu’en 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel a créé la forteresse pour commémorer sa victoire sur les forces tibéto-mongoles. En 1951, un incendie a fait qu’il ne reste que quelques reliques des Drukgyal Dzong, comme l’image de Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. Après l'incendie, la forteresse a été préservée et protégée, restant l'une des attractions les plus sensationnelles du Bhoutan.
mt: Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro district (in the village of Phondey). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire left only a few relics of the Drukgyal Dzong, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining one of the most spectacular attractions of Bhutan.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: Le Drukgyal Dzong est une forteresse et un monastère bouddhiste en ruine dans la partie supérieure du district de Paro (dans le village de Phondey). On dit qu’en 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel a créé la forteresse pour commémorer sa victoire sur les forces tibéto-mongoles. En 1951, un incendie a fait qu’il ne reste que quelques reliques des Drukgyal Dzong, comme l’image de Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. Après l'incendie, la forteresse a été préservée et protégée, restant l'une des attractions les plus sensationnelles du Bhoutan.
mt: Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro district (in the village of Phondey). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire left only a few relics of the Drukgyal Dzong, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining one of the most spectacular attractions of Bhutan.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: Au XVIIIe siècle, le Cambodge s'est retrouvé coincé entre deux puissants voisins, la Thaïlande et le Vietnam. Les Thaïs ont envahi le Cambodge à plusieurs reprises au XVIIIe siècle et en 1772, ils ont détruit Phnom Phen. À la fin du XVIIIe siècle, les Vietnamiens envahirent aussi le Cambodge.
mt: 18th century, Cambodia was caught between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772, they destroyed Phnom Penh. At the end of the 18th century, the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: Les premières informations concernant Taïwan remontent au XVe siècle, tandis que des navigateurs européens passant par là en firent mention sous le nom d’Ilha Formosa, ou « belle île ». En 1624, la Dutch East India Company établit une base dans le sud-ouest de Taïwan, introduisant une transformation des pratiques autochtones de production de céréales et employant des ouvriers chinois pour travailler dans ses plantations de riz et de sucre. En 1683, les forces de la dynastie Qing (1644-1912) prennent le contrôle des zones côtières occidentale et septentrionale de Taïwan et la déclarent province de l'Empire Qing en 1885. En 1895, après sa défaite lors de la première guerre sino-japonaise (1894–1895), le gouvernement Qing signe le traité de Shimonoseki, par lequel il cède la souveraineté de Taïwan au Japon, qui dirige alors l'île jusqu'en 1945.
mt: Taiwan was first mentioned in the 15th century, while European navigators passing through it mentioned it under the name of Ilha Formosa, or "beautiful island". In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a base in southwestern Taiwan, introducing a transformation of the island's indigenous cereal production practices and employing Chinese workers to work in its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces took control of Taiwan's western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after its defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894–1895), the Qing government signed the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it ceded Taiwan's sovereignty to Japan, which ruled the island until 1945.
ref: Taiwan beginning start way back in 15th century where European sailors passing by record the island’s name as Ilha Formosa, or beautiful island. In 1624,Dutch East India Company establishes a base in southwestern Taiwan, initiating a transformation in aboriginal grain production practices and employing Chinese laborers to work on its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces take control of Taiwan’s western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan as a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signs the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it cedes sovereignty over Taiwan to Japan, which rules the island until 1945.

src: C'est ce qu'on appelle le pH d'un produit chimique. Vous pouvez fabriquer un indicateur en utilisant du jus de chou rouge. Le jus de chou change de couleur en fonction de l’acidité ou de la basicité (alcalinité) du produit chimique. Le niveau de pH est indiqué par la quantité d'ions d'hydrogène (le H dans le pH) présents dans le produit chimique testé. Les ions d'hydrogène sont des protons qui ont été dépouillés de leur électron (puisque les atomes d'hydrogène sont constitués d'un proton et d'un électron).
mt: This is called the pH of a chemical product. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The red cabbage juice changes color depending on the acidity or basicity (alkalinity) of the chemical product. The pH level is indicated by the amount of hydrogen ions (the H in the pH) present in the tested chemical product. Hydrogen ions are protons that have been stripped of their electron (since hydrogen atoms are made up of a proton and an electron).
ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

src: Les lions sont les chats les plus sociables, vivant en grands groupes appelés meutes. Les meutes sont composées d’un à trois mâles adultes apparentés, ainsi que d’une trentaine de femelles et de lionceaux. Les femmes sont généralement très proches les unes des autres, leur famille étant composée d'un grand nombre de sœurs et de filles. Les troupes de lions agissent comme des meutes de loups ou de chiens, des animaux étonnamment semblables aux lions (mais pas aux autres grands félins) dans leur comportement, et aussi très mortels pour leurs proies.
mt: Lions are the most social of cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are composed of one to three adult related males, as well as thirty or so females and cubs. Females are generally very close to each other, their family being composed of a large number of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act like wolf or dog packs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in their behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: En dessous se trouvent des félins de taille plus moyenne qui mangent des proies de taille également moyenne, allant des lapins aux antilopes et autres chevreuils. En outre, il existe de nombreux petits chats (y compris les chats de compagnie en liberté) qui mangent les petites proies, bien plus nombreuses, comme les insectes, les rongeurs, les lézards et les oiseaux. Le secret de leur réussite est le concept de niche, une tâche spéciale dévolue à chaque félin, l'empêchant d'entrer en compétition avec les autres.
mt: Below are the smaller cats that eat prey of similar size, ranging from rabbits to antelopes and other deer. In addition, there are many small cats (including feral house cats) that eat the much more abundant small prey, such as insects, rodents, lizards and birds. The secret of their success is the concept of niche, a special task assigned to each cat, preventing it from competing with the others.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: Les ocelots sont friands de petits animaux. Ils attrapent des singes, des serpents, des rongeurs et des oiseaux s'ils le peuvent. Presque tous les animaux que l'ocelot chasse sont bien plus petits que lui. Selon les scientifiques, les ocelots traquent et trouvent les animaux à manger (proies) par l'odorat, en reniflant leur trajet sur le sol. Ils voient très bien dans l'obscurité grâce à leur vision nocturne, et se déplacent aussi très furtivement. Les ocelots traquent leurs proies en se fondant dans leur environnement avant de se jeter sur elles.
mt: Ocelots are fond of small animals. They catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all the animals that the ocelot hunts are much smaller than it. According to scientists, ocelots track and find the animals to eat (prey) by sniffing their trail on the ground. They see very well in the dark thanks to their night vision, and move also very stealthily. Ocelots track their prey by blending into their environment before pouncing on them.
ref: Ocelots like to eat small animals. They will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all of the animals that the ocelot hunts are far smaller than it is. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing for where they've been on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with night vision, and move very stealthily, too. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings then pouncing on their prey.

src: Athlète équilibré, le tigre peut grimper (mais parfois difficilement), nager, sauter de grandes distances et tracter avec cinq fois la force d'un humain puissant. Le tigre fait partie de la même famille (genre Panthera) que les lions, les léopards et les jaguars. Ces quatre félins sont les seuls capables de rugir. Le rugissement du tigre ne ressemble pas au rugissement ample du lion, mais plutôt à une phrase dont les mots seraient des cris et des grondements.
mt: The tiger is a balanced athlete, able to climb (but sometimes with difficulty), swim, jump great distances, and drag with five times the strength of a powerful human. The tiger is part of the same family (genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four felids are the only ones capable of roaring. The roar of the tiger does not resemble the full roar of the lion, but rather like a sentence whose words would be cries and growls.
ref: A well rounded athlete, the tiger can climb (though not well), swim, leap great distances and pull with five times the force of a strong human. The tiger is in the same group (Genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones who can roar. The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

src: Une cellule est la plus petite unité structurelle et fonctionnelle d'un organisme vivant. Cellule vient du mot latin cella signifiant petite pièce. Si vous regardez les êtres vivants sous un microscope, vous verrez qu'ils sont faits de petits carrés ou de boules. Robert Hooke, un biologiste anglais, a vu de petits carrés dans du liège avec un microscope. Elles ressemblaient à des pièces. Il fut le premier à observer des cellules mortes.
mt: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of an organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella meaning small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made up of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, an English biologist, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first to observe dead cells.
ref: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of a living (things) organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella which means small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, a biologist from England, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells

src: Les animaux sont constitués de nombreuses cellules. Ils mangent toutes sortes de choses et les digèrent naturellement. La plupart des animaux peuvent se déplacer. Seuls les animaux ont un cerveau (même si tous les animaux n’en ont pas ; les méduses, par exemple, n’ont pas de cerveau). On trouve des animaux partout sur la Terre. Ils creusent le sol, nagent dans les océans et volent dans le ciel.
mt: Animals are made up of many cells. They eat all kinds of things and naturally digest them. Most animals can move. Only animals have a brain (even if not all animals have one; jellyfish, for example, do not have a brain). You can find animals everywhere on Earth. They dig the soil, swim in the oceans and fly in the sky.
ref: Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.

src: Les plantes produisent de l’oxygène que les humains respirent, et elles absorbent le dioxyde de carbone que les humains exhalent (c’est-à-dire expirent). Les plantes produisent leur nourriture à l'aide du soleil par photosynthèse. Elles fournissent également de l’ombre. Nous fabriquons nos maisons et nos vêtements à base de plantes. La plupart des aliments que nous mangeons sont des plantes. Sans les plantes, les animaux ne survivraient pas.
mt: Plants produce oxygen that humans breathe, and they absorb the carbon dioxide that humans exhale (that is, expire). Plants produce their food using the sun through photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses and clothes from plants. Most of the food we eat is plants. Without plants, animals would not survive.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: Les plantes produisent de l’oxygène que les humains respirent, et elles absorbent le dioxyde de carbone que les humains exhalent (c’est-à-dire expirent). They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: Lorsqu’un petit groupe d’êtres vivants (une petite population) est séparé de la population principale dont il est issu (par exemple, s’il se déplace au-dessus d’une chaîne de montagnes ou d’une rivière, ou s’il se déplace vers une nouvelle île de sorte qu’il ne peut pas facilement revenir en arrière), il se retrouve souvent dans un environnement différent de celui dans lequel il était auparavant. Ce nouvel environnement a des ressources et des concurrents différents, de sorte que la nouvelle population aura besoin de caractéristiques ou d'adaptations nouvelles pour être un concurrent puissant par rapport à ce dont elle avait besoin auparavant. La population d'origine n'a pas changé du tout, elle a toujours besoin des mêmes adaptations. Au fil du temps, à mesure que la nouvelle population s'adapte à son nouvel environnement, elle commence à ressembler de moins en moins à l'autre population. Enfin, après des milliers ou même des millions d'années, les deux populations paraîtront tellement différentes qu'elles ne pourront plus être considérées comme appartenant à la même espèce. Nous appelons ce processus « spéciation », ce qui signifie simplement la formation de nouvelles espèces. La spéciation est une conséquence inévitable et une partie très importante de l’évolution.
mt: When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations in order to be a strong competitor compared to what it needed previously. The original population has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations. Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population. Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they cannot be considered as belonging to the same species. We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.
ref: When a small group of living things (a small population) gets separated from the main population that they came from (like if they move over a mountain range or a river, or if they move to a new island so that they can't easily move back) they will often find themselves in a different environment than they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different features or adaptations to be a strong competitor than what they had needed before. The original population hasn't changed at all, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to their new environment, they start to look less and less like the other population. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the formation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

src: L'organe principal du système cardio-vasculaire est le cœur, celui-ci pompe le sang. Le sang s'éloigne du cœur dans des tubes appelés artères et revient au cœur dans des tubes appelés veines. Les plus petits tubes sont appelés capillaires.
mt: The heart is the main organ of the cardiovascular system, which pumps blood. The blood leaves the heart in tubes called arteries and returns to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: Les insectes ont été les premiers animaux à s'envoler. Leur capacité à voler leur a permis d'échapper plus facilement à leurs ennemis et de trouver plus efficacement de la nourriture et des compagnons. La plupart des insectes ont l’avantage de pouvoir replier leurs ailes le long du corps. Cela leur donne un plus grand nombre de petits endroits pour se cacher des prédateurs. Aujourd'hui, les seuls insectes qui ne peuvent pas replier leurs ailes sont les mouches dragons et les éphémères.
mt: Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape their enemies more easily and find food and companions more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along the body. This gives them more small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and mayflies.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: De nombreux paléontologues pensent aujourd’hui qu’un groupe de dinosaures a survécu et est toujours en vie. On les appelle les oiseaux. Peu de gens les considèrent comme des dinosaures étant donne qu'ils ont des ailes et peuvent voler. Mais il y a beaucoup de choses sur les oiseaux qui ressemblent encore à un dinosaure. Ils ont des pattes recouvertes d'écailles et pourvues de griffes, ils pondent des œufs et marchent sur leurs deux pattes arrière comme des T-Rex.
mt: Many paleontologists think today that a group of dinosaurs has survived and is still alive. They are called birds. Few people consider them to be dinosaurs because they have wings and can fly. But there are many things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have clawed legs covered in scales and lay eggs and walk on their hind legs like a T-Rex.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: Une dentition de tricératops aurait été capable d'écraser non seulement des feuilles, mais également des branches et des racines très dures. Certains scientifiques pensent que le tricératops mangeait des cycadées, un type de plante qui était très courant pendant la période crétacée. Ces plantes ressemblent à un petit palmier avec une couronne de feuilles pointues et hérissées. Un tricératops aurait pu utiliser son bec puissant pour enlever les feuilles avant de manger le tronc. D’autres scientifiques affirment que ces plantes sont très toxiques, il est donc peu probable qu’un dinosaure les ait mangées, même si aujourd’hui, le paresseux et d’autres animaux comme le perroquet (un descendant des dinosaures) peuvent manger des feuilles ou des fruits toxiques.
mt: A triceratops' dentition was capable of crushing not only leaves, but also branches and very hard roots. Some scientists think the triceratops ate cycads, a type of plant that was very common during the Cretaceous period. These plants look like a small palm with a crown of pointed and prickly leaves. A triceratops could have used its powerful beak to remove the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists claim that these plants are very toxic, so it is unlikely that a dinosaur ate them, even though today, the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat toxic leaves or fruits.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.

src: L'équipe nationale italienne de football est, avec l'équipe nationale allemande, la deuxième équipe la plus titrée du monde et elle a remporté la Coupe du monde de la FIFA en 2006. Parmi les sports populaires figurent le football, le basket-ball, le volley-ball, le water-polo, l'escrime, le rugby, le cyclisme, le hockey sur glace, le roller hockey et la Formule 1. Les sports d'hiver sont les plus populaires dans les régions du Nord, les Italiens participant à des jeux internationaux et à des événements olympiques.
mt: The Italian national football team, with the German national football team, is the second most titled team in the world and won the FIFA World Cup in 2006. Among the popular sports are football, basketball, volleyball, water polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, roller hockey and Formula One. Winter sports are the most popular in the northern regions, Italians participating in international games and Olympic events.
ref: Italy's national football, along with German national football team is the second most successful team in the world and were the FIFA World Cup champions in 2006. Popular sports include football, basketball, volleyball, water-polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, roller hockey and F1 motor racing. Winter sports are most popular in the Northern regions, with Italians competing in international games and Olympic events.

src: Le Luxembourg a une longue histoire, mais son indépendance ne date que de 1839. Certaines régions actuelles de la Belgique faisaient autrefois partie du Luxembourg, mais sont devenues belges après la Révolution belge des années 1830. Le Luxembourg a toujours essayé de rester un pays neutre, mais le territoire a été occupé par l’Allemagne pendant les Première et Seconde Guerres mondiales. En 1957, le Luxembourg est devenu l'un des membres fondateurs de l'organisme aujourd'hui connu sous le nom d'Union Européenne.
mt: Luxembourg has a long history, but its independence only dates back to 1839. Certain regions of present-day Belgium were once part of Luxembourg, but became Belgian after the Belgian Revolution of the 1830s. Luxembourg has always tried to remain a neutral country, but the territory was occupied by Germany during both World Wars. In 1957, Luxembourg became one of the founding members of the organization now known as the European Union.
ref: Luxembourg has a long history but its independence dates from 1839. Present-day parts of Belgium were part of Luxembourg in the past but became Belgian after the 1830s Belgian Revolution. Luxembourg has always tried to remain a neutral country but it was occupied in both World War I and World War II by Germany. In 1957 Luxembourg became a founding member of the organization which is today known as the European Union.

src: La Turquie européenne (Thrace orientale ou Roumélie dans la péninsule balkanique) comprend 3 % du pays. Le territoire de la Turquie est long de plus de 1600 kilomètres (1000 miles) et large de 800 kilomètres (500 miles), avec une forme plus ou moins rectangulaire. La superficie de la Turquie, lacs compris, est de 783 562 kilomètres carrés, dont 755 688 kilomètres carrés en Asie du Sud-Ouest et 23 764 kilomètres carrés en Europe. La superficie de la Turquie en fait le 37e plus grand pays du monde et équivaut à peu près à la taille de la France métropolitaine et du Royaume-Uni réunis. La Turquie est entourée par des mers sur trois côtés : la mer Égée à l'ouest, la mer Noire au nord et la mer Méditerranée au sud.
mt: 3% of the country is in European Turkey (Eastern Thrace or Rumelia in the Balkan Peninsula). The territory of Turkey is over 1600 kilometers (1000 miles) long and 800 kilometers (500 miles) wide, with a more or less rectangular shape. The area of Turkey, including lakes, is 783 562 square kilometers, of which 755 688 square kilometers in Southwest Asia and 23 764 square kilometers in Europe. The area of Turkey makes it the 37th largest country in the world and is about the size of France and the United Kingdom combined. Turkey is surrounded by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.
ref: European Turkey (eastern Thrace or Rumelia in the Balkan peninsula) includes 3% of the country. The territory of Turkey is more than 1,600 kilometres (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, with a roughly rectangular shape. Turkey's area, including lakes, occupies 783,562 square kilometres (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 sq mi) are in south west Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,174 sq mi) in Europe. Turkey's area makes it the world's 37th-largest country, and is about the size of Metropolitan France and the United Kingdom combined. Turkey is encircled by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.

src: Le Vatican compte environ 800 habitants. C'est le plus petit pays indépendant au monde, et le moins peuplé. La Cité du Vatican rédige sa législation et ses communications officielles en italien. L’italien est également la langue de tous les jours utilisée par la plupart des personnes qui travaillent dans l’état, tandis que le latin est souvent utilisé dans les cérémonies religieuses. Les citoyens de la Cité du Vatican sont tous catholiques.
mt: Vatican City has about 800 inhabitants. It is the smallest independent country in the world, and the least populated. The Vatican City drafts its legislation and official communications in Italian. Italian is also the language of everyday use by most people who work in the state, while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. Citizens of the Vatican City are all Catholics.
ref: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population. Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.

src: De nos jours, les ordinateurs sont utilisés pour modifier des photos et des vidéos. Les ordinateurs peuvent générer des animations complexes, de plus en plus utilisées à la télévision et au cinéma. On enregistre souvent la musique avec des ordinateurs sophistiqués qui permettent de transformer et mixer des sons ensemble.
mt: Today, computers are used to edit photos and videos. Computers can generate complex animations, increasingly used in television and film. Music is often recorded with sophisticated computers that allow sounds to be transformed and mixed together.
ref: Computers today are used to manipulate pictures and videos. Sophisticated animations can be constructed on computers, and this kind of animation is increasingly being used in television and films. Music is often recorded using sophisticated computers to process and mix sounds together.

src: Les villes de Harappa et Mohenjo-daro avaient des toilettes équipées d’une chasse d’eau dans presque toutes les maisons, reliées à un système d’égouts sophistiqué. Des restes de systèmes d'égouts ont été trouvés dans les maisons des villes minoennes de Crète et de Santorin en Grèce. Il y avait également des toilettes dans l'Égypte ancienne, en Perse et en Chine. Dans la civilisation romaine, les toilettes faisaient parfois partie des bains publics où hommes et femmes se côtoyaient.
mt: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had flush toilets in almost every house, connected to a sophisticated sewer system. Remains of sewer systems have been found in the Minoan houses of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In the Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public baths where men and women mingled.
ref: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had a flush toilet in almost every house, attached to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public bath houses where men and women were together in mixed company.

Remains of sewer systems have been found in the Minoan houses of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In the Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public baths where men and women mingled.
ref: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had a flush toilet in almost every house, attached to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public bath houses where men and women were together in mixed company.

src: La lame d'un patin à glace moderne est dotée de deux extrémités avec un creux concave situé entre les deux. Ces deux extrémités permettent une meilleure adhérence à la glace, même lorsqu'elles sont inclinées. Comme le bas de la lame est légèrement incurvé, lorsque la lame s'incline d'un côté ou de l'autre, le bord qui est en contact avec la glace s'incurve également. Cela fait tourner le patineur. Si les patins penchent vers la droite, le patineur tourne à droite, si les patins penchent vers la gauche, le patineur tourne à gauche.
mt: The blade of a modern ice skate is equipped with two ends with a concave hollow between the two. These two ends allow better adhesion to the ice, even when they are tilted. As the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, when the blade tilts to one side or the other, the edge that is in contact with the ice also curves. This makes the skater turn. If the skates tilt to the right, the skater turns to the right, if the skates tilt to the left, the skater turns to the left.
ref: The blade on a modern ice skate has a double edge with a concave hollow between them. The two edges allow for a better grasp of the ice, even when tilted. Because the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, as the blade tilts to one side or the other, the edge which is in contact with the ice also curves. This causes the skater to turn. If the skates tilt to the right, the skater turns right, if the skates tilt to the left, the skater turns left.

src: Pour retourner au niveau d'énergie précédent, il leur faut se débarrasser de l'excès d'énergie emmagasiné au contact de la lumière. Ils le font en émettant une minuscule particule de lumière appelée « photon ». Les scientifiques appellent ce processus « émission stimulée de rayonnement », car les atomes sont stimulés par la lumière vive, ce qui provoque l’émission d’un photon de lumière (la lumière étant un type de rayonnement). L'image suivante montre les atomes qui émettent des photons. Bien entendu en réalité les photons sont bien plus petits que ceux représentés sur l'image. Les photons sont même plus petits que les particules formant les atomes !
mt: To return to the previous energy level, they must get rid of the excess energy stored by interacting with light. They do this by emitting a tiny particle of light called a "photon". Scientists call this process "stimulated emission of radiation", because the atoms are stimulated by bright light, which causes the emission of a photon of light (light being a type of radiation). The following image shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality the photons are much smaller than those represented in the image. The photons are even smaller than the particles that make up the atoms!
ref: "To return to their previous energy level, they must get rid of the extra energy they got from the light. They do this by emitting a tiny particle of light called a ""photon"". Scientists call this process ""stimulated emission of radiation"" because the atoms are stimulated by the bright light, causing the emission of a photon of light, and light is a type of radiation. The next picture shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality photons are a lot smaller than those in the picture. Photons are even smaller than the stuff that makes up atoms!"

src: Après des centaines d'heures de fonctionnement, le filament dans l'ampoule finit par brûler et l'ampoule électrique ne marche plus. L'ampoule doit alors être remplacée. Il faut être prudent lors du changement de l'ampoule. Tout d’abord, l’interrupteur de l’appareil d’éclairage doit être éteint ou le câble débranché. Cela est dû au fait que le courant électrique qui circule dans la douille, où s'encastre la partie métallique de l'ampoule, peut entraîner des chocs électriques graves si vous entrez en contact avec son intérieur ou sa base métallique alors que l'ampoule est encore partiellement insérée dans la douille.
mt: After hundreds of hours of operation, the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The bulb must then be replaced. Be careful when changing the bulb. First, the light switch must be turned off or the power cord unplugged. This is due to the fact that the electrical current flowing in the socket, where the metal part of the bulb is inserted, can cause serious electrical shocks if you come into contact with its interior or its metal base while the bulb is still partially inserted in the socket.
ref: After hundreds of hours of operation the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The light bulb then needs replacing. It is necessary to be careful in replacing the light bulb. First, the switch for the light fixture needs to be turned off or the cable disconnected. This is because electricity flowing into the socket where the metallic part of bulb sits can give you a severe electric shock if you touch the inside of the socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partly in the socket.

src: La bombe à fission fonctionne selon le principe suivant : elle transforme l'énergie en assemblant un noyau d'une myriade de protons et neutrons. Un peu comme si on faisait gravir une colline à une charrette lourde. En divisant le noyau à nouveau, puis en libérant un peu de cette énergie. Certains atomes ont un noyau instable, de sorte qu'ils ont tendance à se briser avec peu ou pas de pression.
mt: The fission bomb works on the principle that it transforms energy by assembling a nucleus of a myriad of protons and neutrons. A little like if you made a hill climb a heavy cart. By dividing the nucleus again, and then releasing a little of this energy. Some atoms have an unstable nucleus, so they tend to break with little or no pressure.
ref: The fission bomb works on the principle that it takes energy to put together a nucleus with many protons and neutrons. Sort of like rolling a heavy cart up a hill. Splitting the nucleus up again then releases some of that energy. Some atoms have unstable nuclei which means that they tend to break apart with little or no nudging.

src: Lorsque vous appelez une personne qui se trouve à des milliers de kilomètres, vous utilisez un satellite. Le satellite reçoit l'appel dans l'espace puis le renvoie sur Terre, presque instantanément. Le satellite a été envoyé dans l'espace par une fusée. Les scientifiques utilisent des télescopes dans l'espace parce que l'atmosphère terrestre déforme une partie de notre lumière et de notre vision. Il faut une fusée géante de plus de 30 mètres de haut pour mettre un satellite ou un télescope dans l’espace.
mt: When you call someone who is thousands of kilometers away, you use a satellite. The satellite receives the call in space and then sends it back to Earth almost instantly. The satellite was sent into space by a rocket. Scientists use space telescopes because Earth's atmosphere distorts part of our light and vision. It takes a giant rocket over 30 meters tall to put a satellite or a telescope into space.
ref: When you call someone who is thousands of miles away, you are using a satellite. The satellite in space gets the call and then reflects it back down, almost instantly. The satellite was sent into space by a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth’s atmosphere distorts some of our light and view. It takes a giant rocket over a 100 feet high to put a satellite or telescope in space.

src: Le temps est quelque chose qui nous entoure et qui affecte tout ce que nous faisons, et pourtant il est difficile à comprendre. Le temps a été étudié par des érudits religieux, philosophiques et scientifiques pendant des milliers d'années. Nous vivons le temps comme une série d'événements qui passent du futur au passé en passant par le présent. Le temps est également un moyen de comparer la durée (longueur) des événements. Vous pouvez marquer le temps qui passe vous-même en observant la répétition d'un événement cyclique. Un événement cyclique est quelque chose qui se reproduit régulièrement.
mt: Time is something that surrounds us and affects everything we do, yet it is difficult to understand. Time has been studied by religious, philosophical and scientific scholars for thousands of years. We live time as a series of events that pass from future to past through present. Time is also a way to compare the duration (length) of events. You can mark the passing of time yourself by observing the repetition of a cyclic event. A cyclic event is something that repeats regularly.
ref: Time is something that is all around us, and affects everything we do, yet is difficult to understand. Time has been studied by religious, philosophical, and scientific scholars for thousands of years. We experience time as a series of events passing from the future through the present to the past. Time is also how we compare the duration (length) of events. You can mark the passing of time yourself by observing the repetition of a cyclical event. A cyclical event is something that happens again and again regularly.

src: Dans la tradition, l'héritier du trône faisait son service militaire après avoir fini ses études. Cependant, Charles est allé à l’université au Trinity College, à Cambridge, où il a étudié l’anthropologie et l’archéologie, et plus tard, l’histoire, obtenant un 2:2 (un diplôme inférieur de deuxième classe). Charles fut le premier membre de la famille royale britannique à obtenir une licence.
mt: In tradition, the heir to the throne did his military service after finishing his studies. However, Charles went to university at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he studied anthropology and archaeology, and later, history, obtaining a 2:2 (a lower second class degree). Charles was the first member of the British royal family to obtain a degree.
ref: Traditionally, the heir to the throne would go straight into the military after finishing school. However, Charles went to university at Trinity College, Cambridge where he studied Anthropology and Archaeology, and later History, earning a 2:2 (a lower second class degree). Charles was the first member of the British Royal Family to be awarded a degree.

src: L'Angleterre avait connu une longue période de paix après la reconquête du Danelaw. Cependant, en 991, Ethelred a dû faire face à une flotte viking plus importante que toutes les autres depuis celle de Guthrum un siècle plus tôt. Cette flotte était commandée par Olaf Trygvasson, un Norvégien qui avait l'ambition de soustraire son pays à la domination danoise. Après les premiers échecs militaires, Ethereld est parventu à un accord avec Olaf, pour sa part retourné en Norvège afin d'essayer de reconquérir son royaume, pour des résultats mitigés.
mt: 991 was a year of Viking raids in England. The English had enjoyed a long period of peace after the reconquest of the Danelaw. However, in 991, Ethelred had to face a Viking fleet larger than any other since that of Guthrum a century earlier. This fleet was commanded by Olaf Trygvasson, a Norwegian who had the ambition to free his country from Danish domination. After initial military failures, Ethelred was able to reach an agreement with Olaf, who had returned to Norway to try to reconquer his kingdom, with mixed results.
ref: England had experienced a long period of peace after the reconquest of the Danelaw. However in 991 Ethelred was faced with a Viking fleet larger than any since Guthrum's a century earlier. This fleet was led by Olaf Trygvasson, a Norwegian with ambitions to reclaim his country from Danish domination. After initial military setbacks, Ethelred was able to agree to terms with Olaf, who returned to Norway to try to gain his kingdom with mixed success.

src: Vers le 15e siècle, le nord de l’Estonie subissait une forte influence culturelle germanique. Certains moines allemands voulaient rapprocher Dieu des autochtones ; c’est pour cela qu’ils ont inventé la langue littérale estonienne. Il était basé sur l'alphabet allemand et un caractère « Õ/õ » a été ajouté. Au fil du temps, de nombreux mots empruntés à l'allemand se sont mélangés. Ce fut le début du développement.
mt: 15th century, the north of Estonia was under strong German cultural influence. Some German monks wanted to bring God closer to the natives; that's why they invented the Estonian literary language. It was based on the German alphabet and a character "Õ/õ" was added. Over time, many borrowed words from German mixed in. This was the beginning of development.
ref: "Around the 15th century, northern Estonia was under great cultural influence of Germany. Some German monks wanted to bring God closer to the native people, so they invented the Estonian literal language. It was based on the German alphabet and one character ""Õ/õ"" was added. As time passed, many words that were borrowed from German coalesced. This was the beginning of enlightenment."

src: Les estimations sont variées quant au nombre de personnes qui parlent Hindi. On estime que c'est entre la deuxième et la quatrième langue la plus communément parlée au monde. Le nombre de langues maternelles dépend de si oui ou non les dialectes très proches sont pris en compte. Les estimations varient de 340 millions à 500 millions de locuteurs, et jusqu'à 800 millions de personnes peuvent comprendre la langue. L'hindi et l'ourdou disposent d'un vocabulaire semblable mais d'une écriture différente ; lors d'une conversation de tous les jours, les locuteurs des deux langues peuvent en général se comprendre.
mt: Estimates vary as to the number of people who speak Hindi. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most widely spoken language in the world. The number of native languages depends on whether or not very close dialects are counted. Estimates vary from 340 million to 500 million speakers, and up to 800 million people may understand the language. Hindi and Urdu have a similar vocabulary but different writing systems; in everyday conversation, speakers of the two languages can usually understand each other.
ref: There are varying estimates for how many people speak Hindi. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most commonly spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether or not very closely related dialects are counted. Estimates range from 340 million to 500 million speakers, and as many as 800 million people can understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are similar in vocabulary but different in script; in everyday conversations, speakers of both languages can usually understand each other.

src: Le Hangeul est le seul alphabet inventé exprès pour être utilisé dans la vie quotidienne. L'alphabet a été inventé en 1444 sous le règne du roi Sejong (1418 – 1450). Sejong le Grand fut le quatrième roi de la dynastie Joseon et demeure l’un des souverains coréens les plus respectés. À l’origine, il a donné à l’alphabet Hangeul le nom de Hunmin Jeongeum, qui signifie « les sons corrects pour instruire le peuple ».
mt: The Hangeul is the only alphabet invented specifically to be used in everyday life. The alphabet was invented in 1444 under the reign of King Sejong (1418 – 1450). Sejong the Great was the fourth king of the Joseon dynasty and remains one of the most respected Korean sovereigns. Originally, he gave the Hangeul alphabet the name of Hunmin Jeongeum, which means “the correct sounds to instruct the people”.
ref: "Hangeul is the only purposely invented alphabet in popular daily use. The alphabet was invented in 1444 during the reign of King Sejong (1418 – 1450). King Sejong was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty and is one of the most highly regarded. He originally named the Hangeul alphabet Hunmin Jeongeum, which means ""the correct sounds for the instruction of the people""."

He originally named the Hangeul alphabet Hunmin Jeongeum, which means ""the correct sounds for the instruction of the people""."

src: Il existe de nombreuses théories sur la façon dont le sanskrit a vu le jour. L'une d'entre elles concerne une migration aryenne de l'ouest vers l'Inde qui est venue avec sa langue. Le sanskrit est une langue ancienne, celle-ci est comparable à la langue latine parlée en Europe. Le plus ancien livre connu du monde a été écrit en sanskrit. Après la compilation des Upanishads, le sanskrit s'est tout simplement effacé en raison de la hiérarchie Le sanskrit est une langue très complexe et très riche, qui a servi de source à de nombreuses langues indiennes modernes, tout comme le latin est la source de langues européennes telles que le français et l'espagnol.
mt: There are many theories about how Sanskrit came to be. One of them concerns an Aryan migration from the west to India that came with its language. Sanskrit is an ancient language, this is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The oldest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of the Upanishads, Sanskrit simply faded away due to the caste system. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served as a source for many modern Indian languages, just as Latin is the source of European languages such as French and Spanish.
ref: There are many theories to how Sanskrit came into existence. One of them is about an Aryan migration from the west into India who brought their language with them. Sanskrit is an ancient language and is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The earliest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of Upanishads, Sanskrit just faded due to hierarchy. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served to be the source for many modern Indian languages, just like Latin is the source for European languages like French and Spanish.

src: Il existe de nombreuses théories sur la façon dont le sanskrit a vu le jour. L'une d'entre elles concerne une migration aryenne de l'ouest vers l'Inde qui est venue avec sa langue. Le sanskrit est une langue ancienne, celle-ci est comparable à la langue latine parlée en Europe. Le plus ancien livre connu du monde a été écrit en sanskrit. Après la compilation des Upanishads, le sanskrit s'est tout simplement effacé en raison de la hiérarchie Le sanskrit est une langue très complexe et très riche, qui a servi de source à de nombreuses langues indiennes modernes, tout comme le latin est la source de langues européennes telles que le français et l'espagnol.
mt: There are many theories about how Sanskrit came to be. One of them concerns an Aryan migration from the west to India that came with its language. Sanskrit is an ancient language, this is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The oldest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of the Upanishads, Sanskrit simply faded away due to the caste system. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served as a source for many modern Indian languages, just as Latin is the source of European languages such as French and Spanish.
ref: There are many theories to how Sanskrit came into existence. One of them is about an Aryan migration from the west into India who brought their language with them. Sanskrit is an ancient language and is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The earliest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of Upanishads, Sanskrit just faded due to hierarchy. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served to be the source for many modern Indian languages, just like Latin is the source for European languages like French and Spanish.

src: Comment la gravité d’Io pourrait-elle m’affecter ? Si vous vous teniez sur la surface d’Io, vous pèseriez moins que sur Terre. Une personne qui pèse 200 livres (90kg) sur Terre pèserait environ 36 livres (16kg) sur Io. Donc la gravité, bien sûr, vous attire moins.
mt: How could Io’s gravity affect me? If you were standing on Io’s surface, you would weigh less than on Earth. A person who weighs 200 pounds (90kg) on Earth would weigh about 36 pounds (16kg) on Io. So gravity, of course, pulls you less.
ref: How would Io's gravity pull on me? If you stood on the surface of Io, you would weigh less than you do on Earth. A person who weighs 200 pounds (90kg) on Earth would weigh about 36 pounds (16kg) on Io. So the gravity, of course, pulls less on you.

src: La surface de la lune est constituée de pierres et de poussière. Sa couche extérieure est appelée la croûte. L'épaisseur de la croûte est d'environ 70 km sur la face visible et 100 km sur la face cachée. Elle est plus fine au niveau des mers et plus épaisse sous les continents. Il peut y avoir plus de maria sur le côté proche parce que la croûte est plus fine. Il était plus facile pour la lave de remonter à la surface.
mt: The surface of the moon is made of rocks and dust. Its outer layer is called the crust. The crust is about 70 km thick on the near side and 100 km thick on the far side. It is thinner under the seas and thicker under the continents. There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise to the surface.
ref: The surface of the Moon is made of rocks and dust. The outer layer of the Moon is called the crust. The crust is about 70 km thick on the near side and 100 km thick on the far side. It is thinner under the maria and thicker under the highlands. There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise up to the surface.

src: Beaucoup rêvent du jour où nous pourrons voyager vers une autre étoile et explorer d'autres mondes. Pour certains, il s'agit de savoir ce qu'il y a ailleurs, d'autres croient que des extraterrestres ou d'autres formes de vie pourraient vivre sur une autre planète. Toutefois, si cela devait se produire, ce ne serait sûrement pas avant très longtemps. Les étoiles sont si éloignées les unes des autres qu'il y a des milliards de kilomètres entre des étoiles dites voisines. Un jour peut-être, vos arrière-petits-enfants se retrouveront sur un monde extra-terrestre, à s'interroger sur leurs lointains ancêtres ?
mt: Many dream of the day when we can travel to another star and explore other worlds. For some, it is to know what is elsewhere, others believe that extraterrestrials or other forms of life could live on another planet. However, if this were to happen, it would certainly not be for a very long time. Stars are so far apart that there are billions of kilometers between neighboring stars. One day perhaps, your great-grandchildren will be on an extra-terrestrial world, wondering about their distant ancestors?
ref: "Many people dream of the day when humans can travel to another star and explore other worlds, some people wonder what's out there some belive that aliens or other life may live on another plant. But, if this ever does happen probably won't happen for a very long time. The stars are so spread out that there are trillions of miles between stars that are ""neighbors"". Maybe one day, your great grandchildren will be standing atop an alien world wondering about their ancient ancestors?"

src: Le Soleil ne possède pas de croûte comme la Terre sur laquelle on peut se tenir debout. Le Soleil tout entier est fait de gaz, de feu et de plasma. Le gaz se raréfie à mesure que l'on s'éloigne du centre du Soleil. La partie extérieure que nous voyons lorsque nous regardons le Soleil s’appelle la photosphère, ce qui signifie « boule de lumière ».
mt: The Sun does not have a crust like Earth on which one can stand. The Sun is entirely made of gas, fire and plasma. The gas becomes rarer as one moves away from the center of the Sun. The outer part that we see when we look at the Sun is called the photosphere, which means "ball of light".
ref: "The Sun doesn't have a crust like the Earth that you can stand on. The whole Sun is made out of gases, fire, and plasma. The gas becomes thinner as you go farther from the center of the Sun. The outer-part we see when we look at the Sun is called the photosphere, which means ""ball of light""."

src: Environ trois mille ans plus tard, en 1610, l'astronome italien Galilée utilisa un télescope pour observer que Vénus a des phases, tout comme la lune. Des phases se produisent parce que seul le côté de Vénus (ou de la Lune) qui fait face au Soleil est éclairé. Les phases de Vénus ont justifié la théorie de Copernic selon laquelle les planètes tournent autour du Soleil. Puis, quelques années plus tard, en 1639, un astronome anglais du nom de Jeremiah Horrocks a observé un transit de Vénus.
mt: 3,000 years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo used a telescope to observe that Venus has phases, like the moon. Phases occur because only the side of Venus (or the Moon) facing the Sun is illuminated. The phases of Venus justified Copernicus' theory that the planets revolve around the Sun. Then, a few years later, in 1639, an English astronomer named Jeremiah Horrocks observed a transit of Venus.
ref: About three thousand years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei used a telescope to observe that Venus has phases, just as the moon does. Phases happen because only the side of Venus (or of the Moon) facing the Sun is lighted. The phases of Venus supported the theory of Copernicus that the planets go around the Sun. Then, a few years later in 1639, an English astronomer named Jeremiah Horrocks observed a transit of Venus.

src: Le fleuve Amazone est le deuxième plus long et le plus grand fleuve sur Terre. Il charrie plus de huit fois le volume d'eau du deuxième plus gros fleuve. L'Amazone est également le fleuve le plus large de la planète, atteignant parfois 10 km de large. Pas moins de 20 % de l'eau qui se jette des rivières de la planète dans les océans provient de l'Amazone. Le bras principal du Fleuve Amazone est long de 6 387 km (3 980 miles). Il collecte l'eau des milliers de petites rivières.
mt: The Amazon River is the second longest and largest river on Earth. It carries more than eight times the volume of water of the second largest river. The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km (6 miles) wide. Not less than 20% of the water that pours from the rivers of the planet into the oceans comes from the Amazon. The main branch of the Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles) long. It collects the water of thousands of small rivers.
ref: The Amazon River is the second longest and the biggest river on Earth. It carries more than 8 times as much water as the second biggest river. The Amazon is also the widest river on Earth, at times six miles wide. A full 20 percent of the water that pours out of the planet's rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon. The main Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles). It collects water from thousands of smaller rivers.

src: Dix-huit pour cent des Vénézuéliens sont au chômage, et la plupart de ceux qui ont un emploi travaillent dans l'économie informelle. Deux tiers des Vénézuéliens qui travaillent le font dans le secteur des services, près d’un quart dans l’industrie et un cinquième dans l’agriculture. Une industrie importante pour les Vénézuéliens est le pétrole, dont le pays est un exportateur net, même si seulement un pour cent travaille dans l’industrie pétrolière.
mt: 18% of Venezuelans are unemployed, and most of those who have a job work in the informal economy. Two-thirds of Venezuelans who work do so in the service sector, nearly a quarter in industry and one-fifth in agriculture. An important industry for Venezuelans is oil, of which the country is a net exporter, even if only one percent work in the oil industry.
ref: Eighteen percent of Venezuelans are unemployed, and most of those who are employed work in the informal economy. Two thirds of Venezuelans who work do so in the service sector, nearly a quarter work in industry and a fifth work in agriculture. An important industry for Venezuelans is oil, where the country is a net exporter, even though only one percent work in the oil industry.

src: Les corps stellaires dégagent lumière et chaleur à cause de l'énergie créée lorsque les atomes d'hydrogène fusionnent (ou se condensent) pour créer des éléments plus lourds. Les scientifiques travaillent à la création d'un réacteur qui peut produire de l'énergie de la même manière. Ceci, cependant, est un problème très difficile à résoudre et il faudra de nombreuses années avant de voir construire des réacteurs à fusion fructueux.
mt: Stars emit light and heat because of the energy created when hydrogen atoms fuse (or condense) to create heavier elements. Scientists are working on creating a reactor that can produce energy in the same way. However, this is a very difficult problem to solve and it will be many years before we see successful fusion reactors.
ref: Stars give off light and heat because of the energy made when hydrogen atoms are merged (or fused) together to form heavier elements. Scientists are working to create a reactor that can make energy in the same way. This, however, is a very hard problem to solve and will take many years before we see useful fusion reactors built.

src: Eléments et composants sont capables de passer d'un état à l'autre sans se modifier pour autant. L'azote sous forme gazeuse conserve les mêmes propriétés que l'azote liquide. L'état liquide est plus dense, mais les molécules restent identiques. L'eau est un autre exemple. L'eau est composée de deux atomes d'hydrogène et d'un atome d'oxygène. Il a la même structure moléculaire, qu’il s’agisse d’un gaz, d’un liquide ou d’un solide. Bien que son état physique puisse varier, sa structure chimique reste constante.
mt: Elements and compounds are capable of changing states without changing their properties. Nitrogen in gaseous form retains the same properties as liquid nitrogen. The liquid state is denser, but the molecules remain the same. Water is another example. Water is composed of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. It has the same molecular structure whether it is a gas, a liquid, or a solid. Although its physical state may vary, its chemical structure remains constant.
ref: Elements and compounds can move from one state to another and not change. Nitrogen as a gas still has the same properties as liquid nitrogen. The liquid state is denser but the molecules are still the same. Water is another example. The compound water is made up of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. It has the same molecular structure whether it is a gas, liquid, or solid. Although its physical state may change, its chemical state remains the same.

src: Pendant la guerre révolutionnaire, les treize États ont d’abord formé un gouvernement central faible — le Congrès étant sa seule composante — en vertu des articles de la Confédération. Le Congrès n’avait pas le pouvoir d’imposer des taxes et, comme il n’y avait pas de pouvoir exécutif ou judiciaire national, il s’en remettait aux autorités de l’État, souvent peu coopératives, pour faire appliquer tous ses actes. Il n'avait pas non plus le pouvoir de déroger aux lois fiscales ni à celles sur les droits de douane entre les États. Les articles nécessitaient le consentement unanime de tous les États avant de pouvoir être amendés et les États prenaient le gouvernement central tellement à la légère que leurs représentants étaient souvent absents.
mt: During the Revolutionary War, the thirteen states first formed a weak central government — the Congress being its sole component — under the Articles of Confederation. The Congress had no power to impose taxes and, as there was no national executive or judiciary, it relied on the state authorities, often uncooperative, to enforce all its acts. It also had no power to override state tax or tariff laws. The Articles required unanimous consent of all states before they could be amended and the states took the central government so lightly that their representatives were often absent.
ref: During the Revolutionary War, the thirteen states first formed a weak central government—with the Congress being its only component—under the Articles of Confederation. Congress lacked any power to impose taxes, and, because there was no national executive or judiciary, it relied on state authorities, who were often uncooperative, to enforce all its acts. It also had no authority to override tax laws and tariffs between states. The Articles required unanimous consent from all the states before they could be amended and states took the central government so lightly that their representatives were often absent.
